Notes: 'E caudatum': an 'e' grapheme with a tail on the bottom left or left side. It is often (but not always) used to represent an alphabeme 'e' in lieu of which in classical and modern Latin orthography we would have the diphthong 'ae'. When it is not represented by the '√¶' grapheme, it is represeented by a simple 'e' grapheme. It has one allograph with the tail underneath the body of the grapheme, turning right, and a second allograph with the tail on the left of the body (mostly in ligatures).
First found in 5r.a.9 when transliterating a Greek word in Latin.
Found only once in 3r.b.26 (the instance shown in the image in this table)
Space to separate words
Full stop, written on the base line
Middle dot, written at middle heigth
It looks like a comma, written from the middle to the base line. I think that the glyph in image 'punct_triangle.png' (found in 1r.a.18) is an allograph.
Punctuation sign for interrogative sentences. The ink is faded, but it seems to look like a tilde with one dot below only (not with two dots, as it normally is in the Beneventan script).
Punctuation sign looking like a modern colon (:)

Punctuation sign looking like a modern semicolon (;). It might be just an allograph for the grapheme I'm encoding with ¬¶ or for the one I'm encoding with √Ø. It has a bigger vertical size, and a completely different meaning, than the semicolon-like abbreviation mark encoded here with ;
It looks like the sign encoded as ‚Äú|‚Äù, but in addition it has two dots (like a diaeresis) above

This punctuation sign is composed by a comma with two dots above it, in a vertical row. It is used starting from folio 2v, column a, line 35 and seems to be due to the second hand, that writes in black ink.
Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing 'm'. Another option for visualization could be üéó

Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing 's' or 'm'. In 1r its shape resambles a '2' (see abbr_2a.png), then, starting from 1v, it takes a less curved allograph (2b.png). Other options for visualization could be ‚âÄ or ‚∏ä
Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing m'
Macron/tilde over one or more graphemes (over one 'n' means 'non')

It looks like a modern semicolon (;), written on the right of a final letter (mostly 'q;' for 'que' and 'b;' for 'bus'). It has a smaller vertical size, and a completely different meaning, than the semicolon-like punctuation mark encoded here with ≈Ç
A small 'u' written over a 'q'. The 'q-with-≈≥-above' abbreviation means 'qu' (I might just use the regular 'u': TBA)
'p' with a horizontal stroke crossing the descending trait

'p' mostly written with a tail continuing from the round trait of the 'p' on the bottom left side (allograph brev_pro1.png) but also with a separate asterisk or another mark on the same side (allograph brev_pro2.png)
'q' with a horizontal stroke crossing the descending trait
A dash or tilde with one dot above and a comma below, meaning 'est'.
